STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: - First-line treatment per guidelines: For brucellosis, standard therapy is combination antibiotics, typically doxycycline plus rifampin for at least 6 weeks. - Supporting evidence: Combo therapy reduces relapse rates; long duration needed for eradication. - Patient-specific considerations: No contraindications specified; should assess liver function and medication tolerability. - Contraindications or cautions: Avoid drugs with significant hepatotoxicity without monitoring; watch for drug interactions.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: - Primary medication choice: Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily plus rifampin 600 mg daily, for a minimum of 6 weeks. - Rationale for selection: Proven efficacy for brucellosis, well-established dosing. - Expected timeline for improvement: Symptom relief typically within 2-4 weeks; complete eradication in 6 weeks. - Key side effects to monitor: Hepatotoxicity (liver enzymes), gastrointestinal upset, photosensitivity, drug interactions. - Alternative medications if first-line fails: Streptomycin or gentamicin in combination if oral therapy is contraindicated or ineffective.  STEP 4 - NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: - Primary non-drug interventions: Rest, hydration, and supportive care. - Patient education priorities: Importance of medication adherence, recognition of relapse or side effects, safe handling of animals. - Lifestyle modifications: Avoid zoonotic exposure, implement food safety measures. - Behavioral interventions: Stress management techniques if fatigue is persistent; consider counseling if needed. STEP 6 - PATIENT COMMUNICATION STRATEGY: - Communication approach: Clear, compassionate explanation emphasizing the importance of adherence and follow-up. - Addressing patient concerns: Discuss potential side effects, clarify infectious nature, reassure about recovery. - Adherence strategies: Simplify medication routines, provide written instructions and reminder plans. - Family involvement: Encourage family support for medication compliance and to recognize complication signs.  STEP 7 - COORDINATION & REFERRALS: - Specialist referrals needed: Infectious disease specialist for complex management or if treatment resistance occurs. - Other healthcare team members: Primary care provider for ongoing monitoring. - Community resources: Patient education materials on zoonoses, local public health advisories. - Insurance/cost considerations: Confirm medication coverage, consider assistance programs if needed.
